problems.title: Lever
problems.statementHtml:
In Divergent Universe, The Lever iterates itself given two arrays aa and bb of length nn. In each iteration, The Lever will do the following:

After each iteration, the Lever will check if step 11 is ignored, and if so, it will end its iteration.

You're given the two arrays. Find the number of iterations that the Lever does. It can be shown this number is fixed over all possibilities of random indices that The Lever can choose for each step.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (1≤n≤101≤n≤10).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤101≤ai≤10).

The third line of each test case contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (1≤bi≤101≤bi≤10).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output one integer — the number of iterations that the Lever does.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first sample case:

In the first iteration, the Lever decreases a1a1 by 11 and increases a2a2 by 11, and aa becomes [6,4][6,4].

In the second iteration, the Lever decreases a1a1 by 11 and increases a2a2 by 11, and aa becomes [5,5][5,5].

In the third iteration, the Lever increases a2a2 by 11, and aa becomes [5,6][5,6]. Since it fails to decrease an element, its iteration ends. Therefore, the answer is 33.

In the second sample case, the Lever does nothing in its first iteration, and thus it does only one iteration.

problems.title: Alternating Series
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an integer nn. Call an array aa of length nn good if:

Additionally, we say a good array aa of length nn is better than another good array bb of length nn if [|a1|,|a2|,…,|an|][|a1|,|a2|,…,|an|] is lexicographically smaller‡‡ than [|b1|,|b2|,…,|bn|][|b1|,|b2|,…,|bn|]. Note that |z||z| denotes the absolute value of integer zz.

Output a good array of length nn such that it is better than every other good array of length nn.

∗∗An array cc is a subarray of an array dd if cc can be obtained from dd by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the beginning and several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the end.

††An integer xx is positive if x>0x>0.

‡‡A sequence aa is lexicographically smaller than a sequence bb if and only if one of the following holds:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains an integer tt (1≤t≤5001≤t≤500) — the number of test cases.

The single line of each test case contains one integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the length of your array.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (−109≤ai≤109−109≤ai≤109), the elements of your array on a new line.
problems.noteHtml: In the first test case, because a1⋅a2=−2<0a1⋅a2=−2<0 and a1+a2=1>0a1+a2=1>0, it satisfies the two constraints. In addition, it can be shown that the corresponding b=[1,2]b=[1,2] is better than any other good array of length 22.

problems.title: Make it Equal
problems.statementHtml:
Given two multisets SS and TT of size nn and a positive integer kk, you may perform the following operations any number (including zero) of times on SS:

Determine if it is possible to make SS equal to TT. Two multisets SS and TT are equal if every element appears the same number of times in SS and TT.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains an integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases. The description of the test cases follows.

The first line contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105, 1≤k≤1091≤k≤109) — the size of SS and the constant, respectively.

The second line contains nn integers S1,S2,…,SnS1,S2,…,Sn (0≤Si≤1090≤Si≤109) — the elements in SS.

The third line contains nn integers T1,T2,…,TnT1,T2,…,Tn (0≤Ti≤1090≤Ti≤109) — the elements in TT.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output "YES" if it is possible to make SS equal to TT, and "NO" otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, we can remove one occurrence of 11 from SS and insert |1−k|=|1−3|=2|1−k|=|1−3|=2 into SS, making SS equal to TT.

In the second test case, we can remove one occurrence of 44 from SS and insert 4+k=4+8=124+k=4+8=12 into SS, making SS equal to TT.

In the last test case, we can show that it is impossible to make SS equal to TT.

problems.title: Arboris Contractio
problems.statementHtml:
Kagari is preparing to archive a tree, and she knows the cost of doing so will depend on its diameter∗∗. To keep the expense down, her goal is to shrink the diameter as much as possible first. She can perform the following operation on the tree:

It can be shown that the graph is still a tree after the operation.

Help her determine the minimum number of operations required to achieve the minimal diameter.

∗∗The diameter of a tree is the longest possible distance between any pair of vertices. The distance itself is measured by the number of edges on the unique simple path connecting them.

††A simple path is a path between two vertices in a tree that does not visit any vertex more than once. It can be shown that the simple path between any two vertices is always unique.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of the vertices in the tree.

The following n−1n−1 lines of each test case describe the tree. Each of the lines contains two integers uu and vv (1≤u,v≤n1≤u,v≤n, u≠vu≠v) that indicate an edge between vertex uu and vv. It is guaranteed that these edges form a tree.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output one integer — the minimum number of operations to minimize the diameter.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the diameter of the original tree is 33. Kagari can perform an operation on s=3s=3 and t=4t=4. As the figure depicts, the operations includes the following steps:

  1. Remove edges (3,1)(3,1), (1,2)(1,2) and (2,4)(2,4).
  2. Add edges (3,1)(3,1), (3,2)(3,2) and (3,4)(3,4).

After the operation, the diameter reduces to 22. It can be shown that 22 is the minimum diameter.

In the second test case, the diameter of the tree is 11. It can be shown that 11 is already the minimum, so Kagari can perform no operation.

problems.title: Adjacent XOR
problems.statementHtml:
You're given an array aa of length nn. For each index ii such that 1≤i<n1≤i<n, you can perform the following operation at most once:

You can choose indices and perform the operations in any sequential order.

Given another array bb of length nn, determine if it is possible to transform aa to bb.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai<2300≤ai<230).

The third line of each test case contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (0≤bi<2300≤bi<230).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output "YES" (quotes excluded) if aa can be transformed to bb; otherwise, output "NO". You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, you can perform the operations in the following order:

  1. Choose index i=3i=3 and assign a3:=a3⊕a4=7a3:=a3⊕a4=7, and aa becomes [1,2,7,4,5][1,2,7,4,5].
  2. Choose index i=4i=4 and assign a4:=a4⊕a5=1a4:=a4⊕a5=1, and aa becomes [1,2,7,1,5][1,2,7,1,5].
  3. Choose index i=1i=1 and assign a1:=a1⊕a2=3a1:=a1⊕a2=3, and aa becomes [3,2,7,1,5][3,2,7,1,5].

samples.output:
YES
NO
NO
NO
YES
NO
NO

problems.title: Unjust Binary Life
problems.statementHtml:
Yuri is given two binary strings aa and bb, both of which are of length nn. The two strings dynamically define an n×nn×n grid. Let (i,j)(i,j) denote the cell in the ii-th row and jj-th column. The initial value of cell (i,j)(i,j) has the value of ai⊕bjai⊕bj, where ⊕⊕ denotes the bitwise XOR operation. .

Yuri's journey always starts at cell (1,1)(1,1). From a cell (i,j)(i,j), she can only move down to (i+1,j)(i+1,j) or right to (i,j+1)(i,j+1). Her journey is possible if there exists a valid path such that all cells on the path, including (1,1)(1,1), have a value of 0.

Before her departure, she can do the following operation for any number of times:

Let f(x,y)f(x,y) denote the minimum required operations so that Yuri can make her journey to the cell (x,y)(x,y). You must determine the sum of f(x,y)f(x,y) over all 1≤x,y≤n1≤x,y≤n.

Note that each of these n2n2 cases is independent, meaning you need to assume the grid is in its original state in each case (i.e., no actual operations are performed).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains a binary string aa (|a|=n|a|=n, ai∈{0,1}ai∈{0,1}).

The third line of each test case contains a binary string bb (|b|=n|b|=n, bi∈{0,1}bi∈{0,1}).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output one integer — the sum of minimum operations over all possible cells.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the 2×22×2 grid is shown below.

11111111

In the initial state, Yuri cannot reach any cell.

Yuri can flip a1a1 so that the grid becomes:

00110011

and Yuri can travel to cells (1,1)(1,1) and (1,2)(1,2).

On the other hand, Yuri can flip b1b1 so that the grid becomes:

01010101

and Yuri can travel to cells (1,1)(1,1) and (2,1)(2,1).

To move to the cell (2,2)(2,2), it can be shown that she must perform at least two operations. For example, she can flip both a1a1 and a2a2 so that the grid becomes:

00000000

Therefore, the answer is 1+1+1+2=51+1+1+2=5.

problems.title: Wafu!
problems.statementHtml:
To help improve her math, Kudryavka is given a set SS that consists of nn distinct positive integers.

Initially, her score is 11. She can perform an arbitrary number of the following operations on the set if it is not empty:

She is addicted to performing operations, but after kk operations, she realizes she forgot her score. Please help her determine her score, modulo 109+7109+7.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105, 1≤k≤1091≤k≤109).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers s1,s2,…,sns1,s2,…,sn (1≤si≤1091≤si≤109, si≠sjsi≠sj) — the elements of the initial set SS. It is guaranteed that the set SS is not empty before each of the kk operations is performed.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output an integer indicating the answer modulo 109+7109+7.
problems.noteHtml:
Let us simulate the process in the first test case:

{1,3}−→−−−−remove 1{3}−→−−−−add 1,2remove 3{1,2}−→−−−−remove 1{2}{1,3}→remove 1{3}→add 1,2remove 3{1,2}→remove 1{2}

The removed values are 11, 33 and 11 respectively, so her score is 1×3×1=31×3×1=3.

In the second test case, the answer is 1×4×1×2×1×3=241×4×1×2×1×3=24.

problems.title: Sea, You & copriMe
problems.statementHtml:
Umi is given an array aa of length nn, whose elements are integers between 11 and mm. She loves coprime integers and wants to find four distinct indices p,q,r,sp,q,r,s (1≤p,q,r,s≤n1≤p,q,r,s≤n), such that gcd(ap,aq)=1gcd(ap,aq)=1 and gcd(ar,as)=1gcd(ar,as)=1∗∗.

If there are multiple solutions, you may output any one of them.

∗∗gcd(x,y)gcd(x,y) denotes the greatest common divisor (GCD) of integers xx and yy.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (4≤n≤2⋅105,1≤m≤1064≤n≤2⋅105,1≤m≤106).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤m1≤ai≤m).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105, and that the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 106106.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case:

  • If no such set of four distinct indices exists, output one integer 00.
  • Otherwise, output four distinct integers p,q,r,sp,q,r,s (1≤p,q,r,s≤n1≤p,q,r,s≤n) that satisfy the condition. If there are multiple solutions, output any one of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, gcd(a1,a3)=gcd(4,9)=1gcd(a1,a3)=gcd(4,9)=1, gcd(a2,a4)=gcd(7,15)=1gcd(a2,a4)=gcd(7,15)=1.

In the second test case, it can be shown that no such quadruple exists.
